title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Entrance Ticket

Look through your classmates’ links in Forum Response 1 | Shapes and Colors in UR Courses.
There are a lot of the posts, so let’s split them up. If you are at the front of the room, look at posts at top; middle, middle; back, bottom.
If you notice anything that stands out to you, reply with a comment!
Make sure you reply to at least on post by 10:10

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
section: Experience levels in this class vary!
text:
Experience levels in this class vary!
Some students in this class have ten years of coding experiencce. Others have none!
Try not to judge yourself by what other students can do. It’s not a fair race if some started earlier than others.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
section: You can have a one-week extension on ONE of your first two projects.
text:
You can have a one-week extension on ONE of your first two projects.
Otherwise, late work is not accepted.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
section: If average grade is too high, everyone might have their grade reduced.
text:
If average grade is too high, everyone might have their grade reduced.
The average grade should be around 70% to avoid a downward curve. Please adjust your grade expecations accordingly.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
section: Participation is an important part of your grade.
text:
Participation is an important part of your grade.
Your engagement score includes speaking in class, attendance, and in-class activities.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
How to Complete Quiz




Write your first and last name
Write today’s date, Sept. 4
Use black/blue pen or pencil
Only use the left column
Fill in the correct bubble completely
You have twenty minutes

You can reference the syllabus on UR Courses, or I have a few paper copies.
This is the last quiz where you can reference outside materials.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
section: What’s on the Quiz vs. What’s in Class
text:
What’s on the Quiz vs. What’s in Class
Slides and Coding Train tutorials will include the material you need to know for the next quiz.
Demos will cover quiz material and may preview more advanced material.

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
What is p5.js?

A JavaScript library for creative coding
Makes coding accessible for artists, designers, and beginners
Based on Processing programming language
Runs in web browsers

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors

() {} []

^These always come in pairs!

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
createCanvas()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(800, 600);    // width, height in pixels
  createCanvas(400, 400);    // square canvas
}

Creates the drawing canvas
First parameter: width in pixels
Second parameter: height in pixels
Usually called once in setup()
Default size: 100x100 if not specified

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Drawing Basic Shapes: rect()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
  rect(50, 50, 100, 75);     // x, y, width, height
  rect(200, 200, 80, 80);    // square rectangle
}

rect(x, y, width, height)
x, y: top-left corner position
width: horizontal size
height: vertical size
Coordinate system: (0,0) is top-left corner

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Drawing Lines: line()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
  line(0, 0, 100, 100);      // x1, y1, x2, y2
  line(50, 200, 350, 50);    // diagonal line
}

line(x1, y1, x2, y2)
Draws a straight line between two points
x1, y1: starting point
x2, y2: ending point
Line thickness controlled by strokeWeight()

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Understanding RGB Colors
fill(255, 0, 0);     // Pure Red
fill(0, 255, 0);     // Pure Green  
fill(0, 0, 255);     // Pure Blue
fill(255, 255, 0);   // Yellow (Red + Green)
fill(255, 0, 255);   // Magenta (Red + Blue)
fill(0, 255, 255);   // Cyan (Green + Blue)
fill(255, 255, 255); // White
fill(0, 0, 0);       // Black
fill(128, 128, 128); // Gray

Red, Green, Blue values
Each value: 0-255 (0 = none, 255 = maximum)
Mix values to create any color

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
RGB Color System Explained

Additive color model (light-based)
Each pixel has red, green, and blue light components
0: No light (dark/off)
255: Maximum light (brightest)
Combining all three at 255 = white light
All three at 0 = no light (black)

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Code along with me!

or take notes if you prefer

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Key Takeaways

setup(): runs once, initialize your program
draw(): runs continuously, create animations
createCanvas(): set your drawing area size
rect() and line(): basic drawing commands
fill() and stroke(): control colors
rectMode(): change how rectangles are positioned
RGB: mix red, green, blue values (0-255) for any color

title: Gesture/Utterance as Data
text:
Vocal Sketch with TouchDesigner

Get into groups of 3-5
Using one person’s laptop, download the sound-responsive TouchDesigner project from URCourses.
Create a short audiovisual performance, where everyone in your group makes sounds to trigger the image on the screen.
You may also adjust the TouchDesigner project to better suit your performance.
We will share our performances at the end of class. Each group will use the projector to perform.

title: Gesture/Utterance as Data
text:
Before you begin, discuss:

What is your performance about?
What will it sound like? (Music? Theater? What genre? etc.)

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Computer Access
Maker Space and IMP Lab Hours
Tuesday 7-10pm Wednesday 1-7pm

Map Computer Lab ED 440.2
To access the MAP Computer Lab in ED 440.2, students will have to fill out the form, take it to the MAP Art Store, show their student id, and purchase the fob.

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
section: Performance sharing will start in 20 minutes!
text:
Performance sharing will start in 20 minutes!

Remember your peformance should be 30-60 seconds long.
Come up with a title!
Say your names and the title of your performance before you begin.
You will hook up your group’s laptop to the projector and activate the TouchDesigner project live.

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
TouchDesigner Operators

TOPS: Texture Operators (image processing)
CHOPS: Channel Operators (audio and control signals)
SOPS: Surface Operators (3D geometry)
COMPS: Components (containers for networks)
MATS: Materials (shaders and surface properties)
DATS: Data Operators (tables and text data)

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Helpful Shortcuts

Tab: Open operator menu
Spacebar: Play/stop timeline
F1: Enter Performance Mode
Esc: Exit Performance Mode

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Todays Demo CHOPs

MouseIn CHOP: Track mouse position

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
section: Todays Demo TOPs SOPs and COMPs
text:
Todays Demo TOPs SOPs and COMPs

Box SOP: Create a 3D box geometry
Geo COMP: Container for 3D geometry
Camera COMP: Define the viewpoint for rendering
Light COMP: Add lighting to the 3D scene
Render TOP: Render the 3D scene to a 2D image
Transform TOP: Apply transformations to images, including background color

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Other Operators

Box SOP: Create a 3D box geometry
Geo COMP: Container for 3D geometry
Camera COMP: Define the viewpoint for rendering
Light COMP: Add lighting to the 3D scene
Render TOP: Render the 3D scene to a 2D image
Transform TOP: Apply transformations to images, including background color

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Project 1 Requirements

Use input from your computer’s microphone and/or mouse to generate or manipulate visual content in real-time.
The project should run in TouchDesigner and be presented in Performance Mode.
You can activate it as a performance, or have it user-activated (e.g. by mouse movement or sound input).
The project should have a strong conceptual basis and/or be a well-reseearched exploration of a specific aesthetic or visual style

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Workshop your proposals

Get back into your performance groups.
Each person should take 2-3 minutes to read their proposal for Project 1. Feel free to add additional details beyond what you wrote in your forum post.
After each pitch, the rest of the group should provide feedback and suggestions on

Feasibility
Process of making
Conceptual basis
Aesthetic or visual style

Feedback should be respectful, but honest. Consider a compliment sandwich: positive feedback, constructive criticism, positive feedback.
Write down feedback as you will need to revise your proposal based on the feedback you receive.

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text: Next Steps

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Free Writing
Spend five minutes free writing about your project proposal in your notebook (computer closed).

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Revised Proposal
WITHOUT looking at your original proposal (computer closed), write a revised version of your proposal in your notebook. You may look at the notes in your notebook.
The finished proposal should fill up at least half a notebook page. Take a photo of your notebook page to turn in on URCourses.

title: Quantitative Aesthetics
text:
Exit Ticket
Turn in a photo of your notebook proposal on UR Courses, under In-class Exercises > Project 1 Proposal Revision.

title: Bodies of Data
text:
Attendance Policy
Missing more than two classes could lead to a 5% reduction in your final grade. Missing more than three classes could lead to an NP.
You should always come to class when you are well and able, so you can miss class if you are sick.
See syllabus for more details.

title: Bodies of Data
text:

Audio Spectrum CHOP: Analyze audio frequencies

title: Bodies of Data
text:
Modes of Critique
There are many ways to give and receive feedback, and to evaluate a piece of artwork.
For our Project 1 crits (starting next week), we will use the “cold read” method. You will show your work, and your classmates will respond to it without context or explanation from you.

title: Bodies of Data
section: Use this in considering how you will evaluate yourself. What feedback would indicate success for you?
text:
Use this in considering how you will evaluate yourself. What feedback would indicate success for you?
Note that art is not always evaluated on the basis of artist’s intentions, but for this project, we are giving that a try.

title: Bodies of Data
section: What feedback would indicate success for you?
text:
What feedback would indicate success for you?
Note that art is not always evaluated on the basis of artist’s intentions, but for this project, we are giving that a try.

title: Bodies of Data
text:
Measures of Success | Feedback
Do you want your audience to have a specifc emotional response to your work? Do you want them to think about a particular idea? Should it remind them of a particular cultural reference or life experience?
Think of TWO criteria that would indicate success for you. For example:

The audience feels a sense of calm and relaxation when they experience my work.

This should be criteria that you can evaluate on a scale from 1 (unsuccessful) to 5 (very successful).

title: Bodies of Data
text:
Criteria 1 + 2 | Feedback
Do you want your audience to have a specifc emotional response to your work? Do you want them to think about a particular idea? Should it remind them of a particular cultural reference or life experience?
Think of TWO criteria that would indicate success for you. For example:

The audience feels a sense of calm and relaxation when they experience my work.

This should be criteria that you can evaluate on a scale from 1 (unsuccessful) to 5 (very successful).
